goals.question: What is the trend of natural disasters over the years?
goals.visualization: Line chart of the number of disasters per year
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand if there is an increase or decrease in the frequency of natural disasters over time.

goals.question: Which type of natural disaster is the most frequent?
goals.visualization: Bar chart of the count of each disaster type
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us identify the most common type of natural disaster and prioritize our disaster response efforts accordingly.

goals.question: What is the distribution of deaths caused by natural disasters?
goals.visualization: Histogram of the number of deaths
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the severity of natural disasters and the potential impact on human life.

goals.question: Which countries are most affected by natural disasters?
goals.visualization: Map of the count of disasters by country
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us identify the countries that are most vulnerable to natural disasters and allocate resources accordingly.

goals.question: What is the economic impact of natural disasters?
goals.visualization: Stacked bar chart of the cost of damages by disaster type
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the financial impact of natural disasters and prioritize our disaster response efforts accordingly.

code:
```
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data['Year'] = pd.to_datetime(data['Year'], format='%Y')
    data = data.groupby(data['Year'].dt.year).sum()
    sns.lineplot(data=data, x=data.index, y='Disasters')
    plt.title('What is the trend of natural disasters over the years?', wrap=True)
    plt.xlabel('Year')
    plt.ylabel('Number of Disasters')
    return plt

chart = plot(data)
```

```
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load data
data = pd.read_csv('disasters.csv')

# Plot bar chart of the count of each disaster type
sns.countplot(x='Disaster Type', data=data, palette='Set2')

# Set chart title
plt.title('Which type of natural disaster is the most frequent?', wrap=True)

# Rotate x-axis labels for legibility
plt.xticks(rotation=45)

# Show plot
plt.show()
```

```
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load data
data = pd.read_csv('disasters.csv')

# Plot histogram
sns.histplot(data=data, x='Deaths', bins=20, color='blue')
plt.axvline(x=data['Deaths'].median(), color='red', linestyle='--', label='Median: {:.2f}'.format(data['Deaths'].median()))
plt.legend()
plt.title('What is the distribution of deaths caused by natural disasters?')
plt.xlabel('Number of Deaths')
plt.ylabel('Frequency')

plt.show()
```

```
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load data
data = pd.read_csv('disasters.csv')

# Group data by country and count the number of disasters
disasters_by_country = data.groupby('Country')['Disaster Subtype'].count().reset_index()

# Plot the data
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 8))
sns.barplot(x='Country', y='Disaster Subtype', data=disasters_by_country, palette='Blues_d')
plt.title('Which countries are most affected by natural disasters?')
plt.xlabel('Country')
plt.ylabel('Count of Disasters')
plt.xticks(rotation=90)
plt.show()
```

```
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load data
data = pd.read_csv('disasters.csv')

# Convert date fields to date types
data['Start date'] = pd.to_datetime(data['Start date'], format='%m/%d/%Y', errors='coerce')
data['End date'] = pd.to_datetime(data['End date'], format='%m/%d/%Y', errors='coerce')

# Drop rows with NaT values
data = data[pd.notna(data['Start date'])]

# Calculate cost of damages by disaster type
cost_by_type = data.groupby('Disaster Type')['Total Damages ('000 US$)'].sum().reset_index()

# Sort by cost of damages
cost_by_type = cost_by_type.sort_values('Total Damages ('000 US$)', ascending=False)

# Plot stacked bar chart
sns.set_style('whitegrid')
sns.set_palette('husl')
ax = sns.barplot(x='Disaster Type', y='Total Damages ('000 US$)', data=cost_by_type, palette='husl')
ax.set(xlabel='Disaster Type', ylabel='Total Damages (\'000 US$)')
ax.set_title('What is the economic impact of natural disasters?')

# Add value line for highest cost of damages
max_cost = cost_by_type['Total Damages (\'000 US$)'].max()
ax.axhline(y=max_cost, color='r', linestyle='--', label=f'Max cost: {max_cost:,.2f} US$')
ax.legend()

plt.xticks(rotation=45, ha='right')
plt.tight_layout()

plt.show()
```

import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load data
data = pd.read_csv('disasters.csv')

# Convert date fields to date types
data['Start date'] = pd.to_datetime(data['Start date'], format='%m/%d/%Y', errors='coerce')
data['End date'] = pd.to_datetime(data['End date'], format='%m/%d/%Y', errors='coerce')

# Drop rows with NaT values
data = data[pd.notna(data['Start date'])]

# Calculate cost of damages by disaster type
cost_by_type = data.groupby('Disaster Type')['Total Damages ('000 US$)'].sum().reset_index()

# Sort by cost of damages
cost_by_type = cost_by_type.sort_values('Total Damages ('000 US$)', ascending=False)

# Plot stacked bar chart
sns.set_style('whitegrid')
sns.set_palette('husl')
ax = sns.barplot(x='Disaster Type', y='Total Damages ('000 US$)', data=cost_by_type, palette='husl')
ax.set(xlabel='Disaster Type', ylabel='Total Damages (\'000 US$)')
ax.set_title('What is the economic impact of natural disasters?')

# Add value line for highest cost of damages
max_cost = cost_by_type['Total Damages (\'000 US$)'].max()
ax.axhline(y=max_cost, color='r', linestyle='--', label=f'Max cost: {max_cost:,.2f} US$')
ax.legend()

plt.xticks(rotation=45, ha='right')
plt.tight_layout()

plt.show()
